comments:

connected to the repository anymore after starting up with build I20050202-0800.

However, the project containing this file is still connected to the repository.

This seems to be a PDE problem. Although I only imported existing unshared
plug-ins 50% of my shared projects got replaced with a binary version and I lost
all my work.

Moving to PDE.

Our test if a project is shared or not is a simple:
RepositoryProvider.getProvider(IProject).  If it returns null, it's unshared.  
Otherwise, it's shared.

Michael, could this exception result in Team returning null for a shared 
project thus causing Dirk's problem?

No, the above exception would typically occur if a project that was shared by 
CVS was concurrently unshared. Unfortunately, it does not shed any light onto 
why the project was not shared. 

Incidently, you should use RepositoryProvider.isShared(IProject) to test 
whether a project was shared since this can be called without loading the CVS 
plugin.

thanks Michael.

I was not precise enough in comment 2.

When we decide if a project is unshared, calling RepositoryProvider.isShared
(IProject) would not be sufficient, because this will miss all the projects 
that were imported as binary with links.
Linked binary plugin projects are associated with a BinaryRepositoryProvider 
that PDE provides.

so we call RepositoryProvider.getProvider(IProject), if it returns null or an 
instance of BinaryRepositoryProvider, then it's unshared.


Dirk, I feel your loss, but there is no problem with the PDE code that 
determines if a project is shared/unshared.  Therefore, I am closing as 
worksforme.
